head.title: POSTINGS: In Suburbs and 2 New York City Boroughs; House Prices Generally Rise

identified-content.org: New York State Assn of Realtors

hedline.hl1: POSTINGS: In Suburbs and 2 New York City Boroughs; House Prices Generally Rise

abstract.p: New York State Association of Realtors reports average prices for existing single-family homes in some of more suburban counties in and around New York City continued to rise in May; reports prices rose 26.7percent from May 1999 in Westchester County, 10.2 percent in Suffolk County, 8.4 percent in Nassau County, 11.2 percent in Queens and 17.7 percent on Staten Island; prices in Rockland County fell 1.4 percent; sales volume also rose (M)a

block.p: Average prices for existing single-family homes in some of the more suburban counties in and around New York City continued to increase in May compared to prices a year earlier, according to the New York State Association of Realtors.

In Westchester County, the average price rose 26.7 percent, from $442,040 in May 1999 to $560,078 last May. On Long Island, Suffolk County prices rose 10.2 percent, from $188,900 in May 1999 to $208,200 this year. In Nassau County, the increase was 8.4 percent, from $248,800 to $269,700. In Rockland County, however, prices slipped by 1.4 percent over the year, from $261,058 to $257,443.

Average prices for existing single-family homes in some of the more suburban counties in and around New York City continued to increase in May compared to prices a year earlier, according to the New York State Association of Realtors.

In Westchester County, the average price rose 26.7 percent, from $442,040 in May 1999 to $560,078 last May. On Long Island, Suffolk County prices rose 10.2 percent, from $188,900 in May 1999 to $208,200 this year. In Nassau County, the increase was 8.4 percent, from $248,800 to $269,700. In Rockland County, however, prices slipped by 1.4 percent over the year, from $261,058 to $257,443.
In the two city boroughs for which sufficient data was available, prices rose 11.2 percent in Queens, from $179,800 to $200,000, and by 17.7 percent on Staten Island, from $182,453 to $214,711.

Sales volume also rose. There were 150 sales in Rockland in May 2000, 26.1 percent more than the 119 in May 1999. Westchester sales rose only six-tenths of 1 percent, from 464 to 467. In Nassau County, there were 519 sales in May, up 9.3 percent from 475 in May 1999. In Suffolk, the increase was 1.5 percent, from 789 to 801.
Sales on Staten Island more than doubled, to 156 from 77, while transactions in Queens stayed flat, at 285 in May of each year.
